props.header: The Michael C. Carlos Museum collects, preserves, exhibits, and interprets art and artifacts from antiquity to the present.
props.text:
Set in the heart of Emory’s campus, the Michael C. Carlos Museum is a dynamic, interdisciplinary center for the study of art and culture, with collections from Africa; ancient Egypt, Nubia, and the Near East; ancient Greece and Rome; the Indigenous Americas; and South Asia; as well as American and European Works on Paper.

Through our permanent collections, engaging special exhibitions, and innovative programs for audiences of all ages, the Carlos Museum connects the past with the present and the campus with the community. The museum is committed to emphasizing diverse voices, perspectives, and disciplines.

Curators and faculty develop original exhibitions, engage in interdisciplinary research and teaching, and host touring exhibitions that complement our collections and support the teaching mission of the university. The museum’s conservators collaborate with staff, faculty, and students to conduct research and manage preventive care on the museum's varied collections. Museum educators reach across the museum, campus, and city to develop opportunities to engage the intellect and the imagination of university students and faculty, preK-12 students and teachers, and the larger Atlanta community.

props.text: We need to care about our past in order to prepare for our future.

props.title: In 2036, Students Come First
props.body: The Carlos Museum is a center for student flourishing on campus. Emory students collaborate with curators, conservators, and educators to create exhibitions, investigate objects, and explore ideas through great works of art. With your support, 2O36 will further distinguish an Emory education by ensuring students have access to these unique research opportunities.

props.media_text: An investment in 2O36 will facilitate the hiring and retention of curators specializing in pieces from Africa, the Americas, Asia, Egypt, Greece and Rome, and Works on Paper.

props.title: In 2036, Experts Are Essential
props.body: Curators and conservators are essential to the Carlos Museum, leading research and publication of the collections, developing exhibitions, and contributing to the academic vitality of the Emory scholarly community. 2O36 investment in curatorial support will allow the Carlos Museum to hire and retain curators and conservators of the highest caliber as well as provide funding for research, exhibitions, and professional development.

props.title: With 2O36, the Collections Are The Heart of the Museum
props.body: The Carlos Museum collections include art from Africa; Ancient Egypt, Nubia and the Near East; Ancient Greece and Rome; the Indigenous Americas; and South Asia as well as American and European works on paper. With your help, 2O36 will ensure these collections are accessible to the campus and community, through continuous research and scholarship, contemporary exhibition design features, and innovative public programming. Endowment can transform these galleries into nimble and dynamic spaces of learning and wonderment, incorporating the work of contemporary artists and descendent communities in dialogue with museum collections.

props.media_text: With your help, 2O36 will ensure these treasures have a permanent, dedicated home at Emory.

props.title: New Exhibitions Are Headed for 2036
props.body:
Museums are places to explore and discover; to remember where we’ve been and consider how our past shapes our present and our future. While permanent collections shape a museum’s identity, temporary exhibitions engage with those collections in real time- expanding our understanding of them, showcasing new scholarship, and attracting new audiences.

With that in mind, 2O36 will fund the renovation of the Carlos Museum's temporary exhibition galleries and the development of new exhibitions in partnership with national and international collaborators.
props.media_text: 2O36 will fund a special exhibition gallery to house prestigious pieces from national and international collaborators.

props.title: The Carlos Museum Is A Launchpad For Youn Scholars In 2036
props.body: The Carlos Museum supports new scholars by launching their careers at Emory University. Postdoctoral positions offer the opportunity for targeted research focused on important but underserved areas of the Carlos Museum’s extensive and diverse collections. Postdoctoral fellowships allow the museum to broaden and deepen its knowledge production and increase access to its collections through exhibitions and programming. 2O36 support will ensure the Carlos Museum and Emory University promote the careers of young scholars while expanding access and scholarship at the museum.
props.media_text: 2O36 will fund a special exhibition gallery to house prestigious pieces from national and international collaborators.

items.title: In 2036, Experiential Museum Programs Engage Every Emory Student
items.description: The Carlos Museum offers a wide range of academic, informal learning and social experiences, from programs for undergraduates to graduate students and medical school students. With your support, 2036 will further expand student engagement opportunities, developing programs that invite students to deepen their relationship with the Carlos Museum.

items.title: In 2036, Art is For Everyone
items.description: Accessibility is a top priority for the Carlos Museum. By expanding opportunities and accessibility to the museum, 2O36 can ensure that more children, students, and families are able to experience firsthand all the museum has to offer. Extended hours, free days, camp and workshop scholarships, reduced and free admission, and discounted programs for schools are a few examples of how support for this initiative will build our community and ensure everyone has access to experience works of art firsthand.

items.title: In 2036, the Past Speaks to the Present
items.description:
Innovative programming is a hallmark of the Carlos Museum.

2O36 will continue that tradition, launching a new lecture series—Ancients Among Us. In this annual interdisciplinary program, contemporary artists, writers, and thinkers inspired by antiquity will challenge both Emory and public audiences to look anew at our shared human history. As audiences continue to search for surprising and captivating storytelling, the Carlos Museum sees this series as an important contribution to campus and community.

items.title: Conserving The Past for 2036
items.description: The Carlos Museum is the only university museum with an art conservation lab in the region. The Parsons Conservation Lab not only preserves museum objects but also fosters unique training opportunities for students to gain hands-on experience with examination, analysis, preventive care, and treatment. Funding from 2O36 will support essential preservation for a wide variety of materials, as well as continuing research and collaboration initiatives among staff, faculty, and students.

items.title: New Acquisitions For New Stories in 2036
items.description:
Objects tell stories, The Carlos Museum creates and shares new knowledge through the study of objects- not only by museum curators and conservators but by scholars and students here at Emory and around the world and by descendent communities. New acquisitions foster opportunities for teaching and research, scholarly production, and community connection.

When you invest in 2O36, you invest in the museum's ability to inspire our community with meaningful stories about the past that inform our future.

items.title: Empowering Teachers in 2036
items.description: As public funding for education shrinks, it’s more important than ever for the Carlos Museum to provide teachers with the tools they need to connect students to works of art from diverse cultures spanning five continents and nine millennia. 2O36 will generate support for professional development workshops for K-12 teachers, innovative use of technology for connecting the museum and the classroom, and most essential, opportunities for K-12 students to learn from actual works of art in the galleries.

items.title: With 2O36, Technology Tells a Story
items.description:
Museums integrate and use technology to tell stories and connect with audiences. With your support and generosity, 2O36 will ensure that audiences have access to the rich array of information and context that surround works in the collection. From how an object was made and used to how it has been conserved, technology offers a window to a wider experience.

Multimedia guides to the collection, online exhibitions, educational resources, interactive games, video explorations, and three-dimensional models are just some of the ways to expand access and encourage engagement. 2O36 will keep the museum on the cutting edge of these protean technologies.
